awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Making the Invisible Tangible: Reimagining Science Education in Kindergarten through Reality-Based Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent research in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) generated a broad range of interaction styles that move beyond the desktop into new physical and social contexts. These emerging interaction styles, that are often referred to as Reality-based Interfaces (RBIs), leverage users' developmental abilities such as naive physics, spatial, social and motor skills, and offer concrete ways to think about abstract phenomena. Building on this work and motivated by the need of our nation to further engage children in STEM, this research investigates how to design age-appropriate reality-based interfaces that engage young children in scientific investigations, bio-design, and engineering. The project entails the development of novel human-computer interfaces that encourage children to explore and design within the domain of biological engineering, while facilitating learning of abstract concepts in a concrete way. This approach intends to promote a re-examination of the early childhood STEM curriculum to include emerging and interdisciplinary topics.



The project scope includes the design, implementation, and evaluation of RBIs for young children that support collaborative exploration of biological engineering. The research questions investigated focus on how reality-based interaction techniques can be applied to make the invisible tangible. Specifically, how to design novel interaction techniques that bridge the time and size scales of biology? How to design and implement interfaces that supports collaboration within both pairs and larger groups by integrating computational devices of different scales? How to support seamless transition between macroscopic and microscopic levels of information and across multiple devices? And finally, can RBIs allow young children to grasp abstract concepts that were previously considered too complex for their age and developmental stage? The outcomes of this project contribute to four areas of research: 1) tangible and embodied interaction, 2) computer supported collaborative learning, 3) interaction design for children, and 4) early childhood education in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
In this National Science Foundation-funded project (NSF Grant No. 1564018), researchers from the DevTech Research Group from Tufts University and the Human Computer Interaction Lab from Wellesley College partnered to develop a suite of tools for ages K-12 to explore foundational concepts of synthetic biology. Four interfaces were developed as part of this work:

1. CRISPEE- CRISPEE is a tangible, developmentally-appropriate tool to introduce the youngest children to foundational concepts of bioengineering. The CRISPEE prototype is modeled on the real-world CRISPR/Cas-9 gene editing system, and allows children to play with genetic programs to solve real-world problems using an ethical design lens (Grades K-2).

2. Bac2Mars- an educational multi-player video game that engages elementary school children in design of bacteria helpful for sustaining extended research missions on Mars (Grades 1-5). 

3. BacPack - an interactive museum exhibit for engaging visitors in collaborative bio-design for space travel (Grades K-12+).

4. SynFlo - a tangible museum exhibit for engaging visitors in a virtual synthetic biology experiment (Grades K-12+).

In addition to generating new technologies and interfaces, these tools were iteratively tested using a design-based research framework with over 300 children, families, educators, and researchers collectively. Testing tool place at collaborating research sites including the Tech Interactive Museum in San Jose, CA; The Boston Children's Museum in Boston, MA; the Eliot-Pearson Early Childhood Makerspace in Medford, MA; and the Eliot-Pearson Children's School in Medford, MA.

To date, this work has generated outreach and research documentation in the form of:

- 7 peer-reviewed research publications in conference venues such as American Educational Research Association Meeting, Tangible, Embedded and Embodied Interaction Conference, and Interaction Design and Children Conference.

- 3 peer-reviewed research publications in journal outlets such as the Journal of Science Education and Technology, the Journal of Information Technology Education: Innovations in Practice, and the International Journal of Child-Computer Interaction.

- 1 doctoral dissertation for a research candidate at Tufts University

- 5 public outreach events, including TEDxYouth@BeaconStreet (2018), Learn.Design.Compute with Biology at University of Pennsylvania (2018, 2019, 2020), and Global Community BioSummit 3.0 at MIT (2019).

- Curricular resources (including standards aligned curricula and lesson/activity plans) teaching tools (including original storybooks, anchor charts, and classroom worksheets), and technical documentation for all interfaces

Finally, this project supported the students and research assistants to engage in career-developing research activities. Specifically, this project employed and trained:

 - 21 undergraduate students 

- 2 graduate or post-baccalaureate research assistants

- 2 staff people

-1 high school student

Research into the use and learning outcomes of these interfaces and curricular supports suggests that K-12 is a fruitful age range to introduce foundational concepts of biodesign and bioengineering, and that tangible technologies can support children's emerging understanding of concepts related to biology and genetics through the lens of computer hardware and programming languages. Our results also support the idea that children as young as K-2 are cogntively and emotionally prepared to engage in learning around concepts of science, technology, and society, including ethical uses of biodesigned organisms and bioethical considerations for engaging in biodesign work.

For more information about this project, visit the following resource websites:

Tufts University DevTech Research Group Project Page: http://sites.tufts.edu/devtech/research/bioengineering/

Wellesle College Human Computer Interaction Lab Project Page: http://cs.wellesley.edu/~hcilab/tangibac.html

Bac2Mars Project Page: https://cs.wellesley.edu/~bac2mars/
